Jilin University Sino-Japanese Friendship Hospital
Discharge Diagnosis Report
Registration Number: 388
Gender: Male
Age: 56

Discharge Date: 2021-02-07
Length of Stay: 6 days
Discharge Diagnosis: Malignant tumor of the lower lobe of the left lung (small cell carcinoma, T1cN1M0)
Discharge Summary: The patient started coughing and expectorating blood-stained sputum a month ago without obvious cause, no fever, no chest tightness or shortness of breath, and no chest pain, without systematic treatment. Three days before admission, a chest CT scan at a local hospital indicated 'occupation in the lower lobe of the left lung'. The patient came to our hospital for further diagnosis and treatment, admitted from the outpatient department with 'occupation in the lower lobe of the left lung'. During the stay, the patient's mental state was good, with good eating and sleeping habits, normal bowel movements, and no significant recent weight change. After admission, further auxiliary examinations were completed. On 2021-02-03, a robot-assisted radical resection of the left lower lobe cancer, lymph node dissection, bronchoplasty, pleurodesis, and intercostal nerve block were performed. The intraoperative rapid pathology suggested small cell carcinoma. Postoperative symptomatic support treatment was given. Pathology report (672928): (left lower lobe tumor) small cell carcinoma (tumor size 2.3*1.5*0.6 cm), intravascular cancer thrombus, nerves not involved; (673038) (left lower lobe residual) malignant tumor, supported by pathology no. 672928 immunostaining results for small cell carcinoma, not involving the visceral pleura, focally involving the full thickness of the bronchial wall, intravascular cancer thrombus, nerves showing cancer involvement, no lesions seen at the bronchial and pulmonary portal vein ends, lymph node metastatic cancer, PTNM: T1cN1Mx. The patient's general condition was good, vital signs stable, no fever, and no significant discomfort. The patient recovered well, meeting the discharge criteria. After explaining the condition to the patient and family, and upon their request for discharge, approval was sought from the senior physician, and discharge procedures were completed with instructions for aftercare.
Discharge Instructions and Cautions:
1. Ensure rest, adjust diet reasonably, complete rest for one month;
2. Change dressings every 2-3 days, remove remaining sutures depending on wound healing;
3. Return to hospital for comprehensive anti-tumor treatment after one month;
4. Regular follow-up at the thoracic surgery outpatient clinic;
5. Follow up if there are any changes in the condition.
Senior Physician's Signature: Feng Hua
Physician's Signature: Zui Ruifo
Date: 2021-02-07
Note: Two copies of this diagnosis report are issued, one for the patient to keep, one for the medical institution.JSON result:

Daqing Oilfield General Hospital
Admission Record
Department: Oncology Department One
Bed Number: 1-J006
Patient Summary: Female, 57 years old, admitted due to 'diagnosed lung cancer for over 5 months, undergoing 5 cycles of chemotherapy.' The patient began experiencing intermittent dry cough in March 2023 without an obvious cause, occasionally coughing up a small amount of white phlegm, no fever, no hemoptysis, no chest pain, cough more noticeable at night, no general weakness, no muscle soreness or joint pain. Outpatient lung CT indicated a space-occupying lesion in the left lower lung with multiple nodules in both lungs and a left adrenal mass. Routine blood tests showed no abnormalities. Visited our respiratory department for a fiberoptic bronchoscopy biopsy; pathology showed adenocarcinoma at the base of the left lower lobe, with genetic testing indicating KRAS G12A and STK11 mutations. Our hospital's PET-CT showed significant FDG metabolism increase in the left lower lobe lesion, consistent with malignancy characteristics, suggesting a high possibility of left lung cancer. Multiple nodules in both lungs with abnormally increased FDG metabolism, suggesting widespread metastatic tumors. Mild FDG metabolism increase in the left adrenal area, follow-up recommended. Bilateral cervical lymph nodes enlarged, some with increased FDG metabolism; mediastinal, bilateral axillary, pelvic, and bilateral inguinal small lymph nodes with no significant increase in FDG metabolism, clinically correlated. On 2023-04-20 and 2023-05-11, the patient underwent chemotherapy with pemetrexed 0.8g ivgtt + carboplatin 500mg ivgtt + bevacizumab 700 ivgtt q21d. On 2023-05-31, ALT 266 U/L and AST 141U/L were checked at Daqing City Traditional Chinese Medicine Hospital; underwent hepatoprotective treatment at our hospital, then continued the original chemotherapy regimen from 2023-06-06. The patient came to our outpatient clinic for ongoing treatment, after reviewing relevant data, was admitted to our department with 'malignant lung tumor'. During the course, the patient had no dizziness, headache, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, abdominal distension, or abdominal pain, no frequent urination, urgency or painful urination, no change in urine color, good diet, sleep fairly well, normal bowel movements, no weight change. General condition fair, conscious, fluent speech, stable breathing, walked into the examination room, cooperative during examination. No appearance of anemia, no facial edema, skin and mucous membranes without cyanosis or pallor, bulbar conjunctiva without congestion or edema, eyelid conjunctiva without pallor, sclera without jaundice, lips without cyanosis, throat without congestion, bilateral tonsils not enlarged, surface without purulent coating, neck soft, jugular veins not distended, trachea central, chest cage symmetrical, clear breath sounds in both lungs, no dry or wet rales heard, heart rate 96 beats/min, rhythm regular, no pathological murmurs heard in valve areas. Abdomen soft, no tenderness or rebound pain, no muscle tension, liver and spleen not palpable under ribs, no edema in lower limbs. Neurological examination showed no positive localization signs.
Clinical Preliminary Diagnosis:
1. Maintenance chemotherapy for malignant tumor
2. Targeted therapy for malignant tumor
3. Malignant lung tumor
4. Mediastinal lymph node secondary malignant tumor
5. Secondary malignant lung tumor
Diagnosing Physician: Ma Xiaobin
Diagnosis Date: August 9, 2023.JSON result:

Tianjin Cancer Hospital
Discharge Record
Patient ID: 528629-9
Gender: Female
Age: 64
Department: Interventional Oncology
Admission Date: 2022-04-24
Discharge Date: 2022-04-28
Length of Stay: 4 days
Admission Details: On May 9, 2018, a physical examination revealed a mass in the left lung, confirmed by a chest CT scan at Tianjin People's Hospital on the same day. No bone metastasis was seen on an ECT performed on May 10, 2018. The patient was hospitalized at Tianjin General Hospital, where a chest enhancement CT on May 14, 2018, showed a mass in the posterior segment of the left upper lobe, approximately 41*34mm, suspected of lung cancer. Diffuse small nodules in both lungs were considered metastatic. Multiple lymph nodes in the lungs and mediastinum were partially slightly enlarged. Both pleurae were thickened. A BUS endoscopic ultrasound on May 15, 2018, and a pathology report on May 22, 2018, indicated non-small cell lung cancer, with immunohistochemical staining positive for CK7, NapsinA, TTF-1, CAIX, CD10, and negative for CDX2, CK20, Villin, consistent with adenocarcinoma. Initially considered metastasis from renal clear cell carcinoma due to (subclavicular lymph node puncture smear) heterogeneous cells visible. A consultative pathology at our hospital on May 22, 2018, confirmed 1) adenocarcinoma of the left lung, immunohistochemically consistent with primary lung origin and 2) nuclear heterogeneity in cells from brushings and subclavicular lymph node puncture smear. Immunohistochemistry: CK7+, NapsinA, TTF-1+, CAIX nuclear+, CD10+ all positive, CDX2-, CK20-, Villin-, Vimentin-. Diagnosis of left lung cancer PS: adenocarcinoma CS: Stage IV (bilateral lungs). Underwent 6 cycles of chemotherapy from May 26, 2018, to September 8, 2018, and stereotactic radiotherapy from September 11, 2019, to September 18, 2019. A chest CT on January 17, 2022, compared to October 28, 2021, showed reduced hepatic steatosis, no other significant changes. A chest CT on April 11, 2022, compared to January 17, 2022, showed multiple nodules in the right lower lobe had enlarged, no other significant changes. Admitted for further treatment after ruling out COVID-19 in the outpatient clinic.
Hospital Course: After admission, necessary examinations were completed, confirming bilateral malignant lung tumors. To control disease progression, after completing preoperative preparations, the patient underwent percutaneous puncture for implantation of radioactive particles in the lung tumor under local anesthesia. Postoperatively, hemostasis and fluid resuscitation were provided as supportive care. The patient recovered well and was discharged.
Discharge Condition: The patient's vital signs were stable, general condition good, heart sounds strong and regular, clear breath sounds in both lungs, abdomen soft, liver and spleen not palpable beneath the ribs, no abdominal tenderness or rebound pain, shifting dullness negative.
Discharge Diagnosis: 1. Bilateral malignant lung tumors
Discharge Instructions:
1) Ensure rest and nutrition.
2) Regular follow-up visits.
3) Follow up if there are any changes.
Physician's Signature: Liu Fang, Li Yong.JSON result:

Brief Medical Condition and Diagnosis:
The patient was admitted for 'diagnosed right lung small cell carcinoma for over a month'. Prior to and upon admission, routine examinations were completed. Treatment plan was set by Chief Physician Zhao Jun. The patient's right lung small cell carcinoma is staged as cT1cN1M1b IVA extensive stage. Treatment chosen includes etoposide, carboplatin, and durvalumab. After ruling out contraindications, treatment started on 2023-09-05 with etoposide 100mg/m2,200mg d1-3; carboplatin AUC=5 600mg d1; durvalumab 4.5mg/kg 400mg d1; q21d, supplemented with antiemetics, liver protection, and gastric protection. The treatment process was smooth. After the previous chemotherapy cycle, the patient experienced Grade 3 leukopenia and neutropenia, post-treatment prophylactic measures for leukocyte elevation were given. The patient had a tooth extraction on 2023-09-01, and to avoid complications such as osteonecrosis of the jaw, treatment with denosumab was temporarily halted. The patient has now completed this treatment cycle, general condition is satisfactory, and discharge was approved by the senior physician.
Treatment Recommendations: 1) Use long-acting leukocyte elevation injections 48 hours post-discharge, regularly check complete blood counts, liver and kidney functions (1-2 times/week), and seek outpatient treatment if abnormalities are found;
2) Next treatment cycle (3rd cycle) is scheduled for September 26, 2023. Contact the hospital administration 7 days in advance to schedule a bed, prepare hospital admission documentation, and bring results of blood counts, liver and kidney functions, electrolytes, cardiac enzymes, lipase, amylase, thyroid function, and ECG from the past three days upon admission;
3) After this treatment cycle, reassess effectiveness including chest enhanced CT, abdominal and superficial lymph node ultrasound;
4) Ensure rest, avoid infections, and seek follow-up for any discomfort.
Discharge Diagnosis: Right lung small cell carcinoma cT1cN1M1b IVA extensive stage, metastasis to the right lung hilum lymph nodes, L4 vertebra, left iliac bone, hepatitis B, unstable angina, and high blood pressure stage 3 (very high risk), constipation, bone marrow suppression post-chemotherapy (leukopenia and thrombocytopenia).
